review_title: Save yourself the trouble - Apply elsewhere!
pros: Hard to find pros (if any exist). Gave 6 interviews for this position, was offered the job and turned it down. They make you work SO much, with various case studies and skill assessments as if they're BCG or McKinsey. Their offer was laughable. With every interview I cleared, they kept bringing the comp down by $2-3K. Was surprised a company like MGB has to pinch pennies, while looking for good talent. Its as if they're doing you a HUGE favor by offering you employment (Which you're qualified and able for)
cons: Best thing I ever did was to know my worth, and said no to them. A month or two later, I got a job with a great company with the comp almost twice of what MGB offered. Not $5-$10K more, almost double! And they tell me how happy they are to have me, and I am super motivated to excel here!

review_title: Healthy work/life balance with job security but little chance for growth
pros: PHS is an enormous company with many different landscapes.  I can't comment on departments outside of IS, but in 3.5 years in the IS department, a healthy balance between work and play was encouraged.  Partners Corporate offers a wonderful vacation package (3 weeks + 9 floating holidays + 2 weeks that you may "buy" at your "hourly rate").  The benefit package is also generous, partially reimbursing employees for computer purchases, adoptions, etc. and subsidizes commuting charges.  I only paid 135$ a month for my 380$ monthly parking pass at the Prudential Center.  It was a safe, low-stress work environment where more junior employees were mentored and given opportunities to grow.  Additionally, there was much job security, as people tended to stick around for years, and the company seemed to keep them on regardless of their abilities and performance.
cons: The downside of working at a very large company (40,000+ employees) is the red tape one has to wade through to get things done.  Additionally, there are rigid rules in place that can't be bent to suit a situation.  Employees with minimal years of experience are compensated based on that, NOT their contributions and value to the company, and employees often feel their welfare has nothing to do with their job performance.

review_title: Often overworked, overstressed, underpaid, understaffed, and other somewhat negative adjectives.  (Information Systems)
pros: Work with latest technology; co-workers willing to help out; never lacking for things to do.  Ostensibly it's a good thing to work for an amalgamation of research hospitals, but the realities of the work far outweigh the touchy-feeliness of the *idea* of working there.
cons: Interview process did not involve peers, so poor vetting of candidates.  Little in the way of guidance.  Assumption that employees will be willing to work lots of hours after the end of the workday much of the time.  On-call was mind-bogglingly bad.  Very poor organizational structure -- poor staffing levels, poor training; no individual empowerment to allow improvement of organization.  Lots of finger-pointing and under-the-bus throwing.  Lots of 'institutionalized' workers -- 'lifers', you might say.  Too many projects that are deemed 'top priority,' so everyone bends over backward and works too hard too quickly to satisfy too many people in positions of power.  Over-reliance on the mantra "it is what it is," suggesting that change does not happen easily or willingly.  And remarkably mediocre benefits for a healthcare non-profit (including having to buy additional time off).  PHS has lots of money, but also a great deal of institutional arrogance, and isn't afraid to throw its weight around.

review_title: A good place to get Epic experience and leave for more money and recognition
pros: Depending on your team, there can be some flexibility in your work schedule (WFH, etc.). This is entirely driven by the manager, though, and micromanagers will not allow working remotely, while someone you work with on another app can work remote on snow days or Fridays. At least on the Epic project a pro was getting certifications paid for, which can be invaluable.
cons: Benefits aren't *great*, despite what some are saying. Time off is very minimal. You get three "weeks off", but all PTO is pooled, meaning if you have the misfortune of getting sick for a week, you lose a week of your vacation time. Absolutely incredible that a healthcare organization would penalize workers for taking sick time. No match on 403(b), and the cash retirement plan is nice, but only benefits those who are lifers here. Very low raises (1-3% a year) discourage the "last-ins", and younger, talented types to stay more than a few years as they were inflexible on negotiating starting salary. Lots of family members or friends-of-friends in the company, so losing the aforementioned talent means there can be a lot of mediocrity throughout the organization. No room for upward movement for many given that. Way too much policy and procedure which is largely a construct to legitimize the employment of fringe employees.

review_title: Good place to build a health care career, but beware of the bureaucracy...
job_title: Client Services Representative in Boston, MA
pros:
Partners is one of the strongest health care players in New England, and working there means working with some of the best hospitals in the country. If you are looking to build a healthcare career in the Greater Boston area, this is a great place to start.

The company offers good pay and great benefits, as well as a vast array of career opportunities for clinical and administrative healthcare professionals alike.
cons:
As one of the largest integrated health systems in the country, Partners has a bureaucratic organizational structure that can be frustrating if not exceedingly difficult to navigate. At the same time, while the company's 501(c)3 nonprofit status helps it to maintain a focus on its mission to provide quality patient care and research, it has a distinctly corporate culture that one could argue is "nonprofit" by name only.

Additionally, it is worth noting that there is a nationwide trend in which large health networks have moved to strengthen their market share by acquiring smaller community hospitals, research centers and physician practices within their region. With ever greater bargaining power, these health networks put upward pressure on prices and, in doing so, can challenge the affordability of health care services for many patients. Make no mistake: Partners is one of the organizations that has led this charge.

review_title: Do more with less; Industry demands for cost savings are causing increasing stress in the day-to-day
pros:
1. The highly credentialed, highly motivated people that live to make this world better than they found it will be your co-workers. Read Atul Gawande's Check-List Manifesto 
2.  Staff skill development is encouraged by leadership. They promote from within.
3.  Benefits are great, "the Cadillac" of healthcare coverage 
4.  Have mother's rooms at some locations equipped with a mini fridge for proper storage of breast milk.
cons:
1. HR is unresponsive to everyone.  It's so bad that the department is a joke referenced in staff meetings.
2.  If you do exceptionally well in a year you are never rewarded.  Raises are capped at 2% if you are a star. However, you will have an increased workload & get recognized by the company with a printed certificate of excellence.
Best option is to go for a promotion.
3.  Work-life balance is going away. While they're offering alternative options like remote work from home, it's still rediculous to be expected to work 40hrs plus finish decks at home and check emails at odd hours b/c the work load per person is just sky rocketing.  The management doesn't understand how to do more with less money unless they are cutting staff and asking new hires to do twice the job.

review_title: Going downhill as a place to work
job_title: Healthcare Data Analyst in Somerville, MA
pros: Friendly people, not cut-throat, cash balance plan, 403b match, new building, some jobs allow remote work, casual attire allowed
cons: No reward for performance - just a 2% raise.  This is no longer keeping up with inflation!  The salaries are not staying competitive for the market for high-skilled workers, all of our new employees are fresh out of grad school. Total lack of transparency from HR on how to get promoted and what pay ranges are for a job.  Managers lack the same information.  The worst is the change from BCBS to Allways (formerly and better know as Neighborhood Health Plan) for medical insurance. This was sold to us as having little effect and that "almost all" of providers took it.  The reality is that very few mental health providers outside of those in Partners own network will take this product (administered by Optum - another fact that was not communicated to us).  This is an awful thing to do to your employee's mental health.  Furthermore, you will pay large co-pays if you decide to go outside of the Partners network for medical care.  Very disappointed in the organization for making this move to try to salvage the failing insurance product that they hastily purchased (NHP).

You're the boss - and some people get sour when they are told what to do by someone else. Every time I went to the AM/PD with an issue or problem, she took me seriously and helped guide me in the right direction. If something needed to be escalated to a higher level, she would do so.

I know this can vary tremendously, but I've been able to work for some of the most competent managers who have given me freedom to be creative in my roles supporting training and taught me a lot about how to be more effective. review_title: For a healthcare company, they sure don't care about the employees' health
pros: The people who work in the Family Practice office that I worked in, are really wonderful.  They care deeply for the patients they treat.
cons:
The working conditions in the reception department where I worked was horrible.  3 people, including computers and printers and files for patient prescriptions, working in a space 10' X 8'.  I was closed into this closet-like space for 8 hours a day; when training 2 new people this spring, there were 5 of us working in the cramped space.  Because it was a family practice, we saw sick people every day and the ventilation was broken so the germs were locked in with us.  

The orientation materials were misleading; the Earned Time Off policy is billed as 5 weeks time off but your ETO is used for holidays, days where the office closed for severe weather, so that you never have any real time off for vacations.  And, because of the lack of ventilation, people get sick often.  Your accrued sick time cannot be used until all your ETO is used, so there really is no available sick time.   When they closed the office for snow days - this year we were closed 2.5 days - there was no possibility of choosing to not be paid.  It was mandatory that ETO be used!

job_title: Health Policy and Contracting Specialist in Somerville, MA
pros:
- Those who aren't in leadership positions in the department are usually kind and helpful. 
- benefits are great.
cons:
- Extremely high turnover in the PS&C department due to mismanagement and unsustainable work loads. 
- People are afraid to ask questions because of the management treating those that do as unintelligent and "aloof" to what's going on. 
- Micromanaging is a major issue.
- Promotions are extremely rare.
- Work culture is poor, below average at best. 
- At Day 1 new employees are treated as if the leadership expects them to fail. Constantly feels like you're fighting for your job throughout your first 90 days: you're expected to present a 90 day presentation to the VP and two directors who then meet after you've left the room to discuss your future in the department. 
- All of these cons were raised during an Employee Engagement Survey that was performed in July 2018, but nothing was done to address these issues except to allow two work from home days a week instead of one (everyone is too scared to take both of these days due to negative feedback from their bosses)
- there is zero consideration for work/life balance.

review_title: North Shore Medical Center needs serious improvement
pros: Cell phone discounts, health insurance is decent but only if you're full-time (part time employees are charged way more, and most of their check goes to coverage)

I've seen many co-workers who had been employed there for decades and in good standing get tossed aside, and replaced by lower paid substitutes by reducing their hours drastically and then taking new and cheaper hires. Nurses were on strike recently, and employees at Union Hospital are furious from their site being closed down. It's seriously a mess there now, and has been for awhile but it used to be a great place to work.

review_title: EPIC. It all depends where you land & who you work for.
job_title: IT Project Manager in Boston, MA
pros: Benefits are great. Working directly with MDs and Administrators on a hospital campus is rewarding and educational.  That isn't the case in Charlestown or DTX.
cons:
As a Project Manager, 99.9% of the 60+hour workload was administrative/clerical (not managing/directing/guiding anything). Working directly for the consultants (as a Partners employee) was not well thought. Training and knowledge transfer were glossed over - at best. Consultants were definitely a clique and kept Partners employees at a distance, not sharing information/resources as freely as they did with each other. 

Turn over and burn out are the norm. Consultants cycle through the project with regularity and Partners employees are doomed to just burn out trying to keep pace. No incentives to keep up the pace either as the pay is substandard and there is no place to jump to within Partners when the project ends.

Other Project Managers felt the same.  No (zero) work/life balance.

job_title: Applications Analyst II in Boston, MA
pros: Partners provided a work opportunity to me after being laid off from a prior position.  Partners offers remote work opportunities (I work from home 2 days per week,) good work/life balance, decent medical benefits and perks (discounts on goods and service purchases.)
cons: The open floor plan in my office is awful for productivity and the salary is low relative to what I was being paid to do similar work at another company.  The paid time off is not that great -- all your holiday, vacation and sick time are bundled into one pool -- and you don't accrue a lot until you're at the company for a long time.   You can buy up to 10 days, but at what Partners pays you,  this can be somewhat challenging.

The company cares about it's employees in that they give bonuses, allow lateral movement (promotion from within), offer good benefits, and just have perks and employee morale boosters. I really sometimes wish I wouldnt have left but I was not a fan of the wider city.
cons: Sometimes there can be a little bit of politics or people from other departments (aka The Suits) throwing their weight around but I suppose this is inevitable of any multifaceted organization with so many elements. Direct hire seems tricky to obtain for my department. Generally it's good to know of somebody and an opening if you are working your way in from the bottom. My department was 24hr operation which cuts into life in the city. Parking likely sucks if you can not take public transportation to most of the dense hospitals.

pros: Very stable, well-managed company with excellent work/life balance including telecommuting options. Working in corporate IS is really "enterprise-level" work that impacts millions of people across Eastern Mass. Even with the Epic migration it's still more stable than most companies. Good technology, there are legacy systems to be supported but there's always new/upgraded systems as well.
cons: The downside of being such a stable company is that you pretty much work in the same area, year after year, with the same 2% raise every year; your hard work is appreciated among your immediate colleagues but you're not going to revolutionize healthcare and get rich as an individual contributor in IS. Under the previous CEO/CIO IS was a strategic growth area, while they aren't necessarily cutting back right now they're not growing either.

review_title: Promoting from within is admirable UNTIL it means more of the same old thing.
job_title: Senior Network Engineer in Boston, MA
pros: Benefits are great.  Salary is good.  Location is very good.  Being a part of something bigger than just your job is rewarding.
cons: While there is some very leadership at the top, the narrow-vision in filling mid-level and senior-level management slots is disappointing.  We had a position open and after a search where an external candidate was head and shoulders over internal candidates, they chose the internal guy.  Now we have another Corporate Director position open and everyone is waiting to see what happens.  It would be nice to get someone who can manage and who has technical skill, but they will probably select another internal guy.  Promoting from within is great, but it can be very stagnating as it can promulgate a "group think" mentality.  We lost out on a woman who could have led us in interesting directions for 'more of the same' and I, for one, will not be surprised if this happens again.

review_title: Noble cause, welcoming culture, smart people
pros: Noble cause, welcoming culture, smart people, good location at assembly row, good pay, good health insurance
cons: Poor 401k match and only starts after a year of employment, no performance based bonuses (haven't been through a year end review yet, so not sure what yearly pay increases look like),  inability to negotiate more than 2 weeks vacation time - I went from 4 weeks in previous role to 2 weeks here, intranet site doesn't include all employee reference tools all in one place

job_title: Applications Analyst II in Wellesley, MA
pros:
- Phenomenol world class talent in a world class organization, even in IT
- HIT projects out of star wars, things you can only dream of in the corporate world
- Tremendous Clinical R&D opportunities
- Potential to move around in the organization
- PHS influences not only the US but the rest o the developed world
cons:
- No upward mobility in IT. You do what you do and that's that
- Stagnant management tenure. Same folks in the same position for 15-20 years. No room for new talent.
- 25-40% lower salaries in IT compared to industry (it's your 'privilage to work here - remember that)
- No new innovation since Epic is in the house

review_title: Great place to work with awesome mission and bens
pros: I've worked at Partners for over 8 years and it has been an amazing place to work. The benefits are great (they only cost me $1.56/week for medical, dental, and vision) and the work is great. I think people forget why you work at a place like Partners. Do you work there because it's a job? To help with patient care? Both? I work in Partners eCare and while it has been demanding, I don't lose site of the overall purpose of the work which is to improve patient care. Sure there are areas of improvement, but I think the job here is what we make of it.
cons: The work can be demanding and hard on work/life balance but most managers listen when you need a break. HR set the stage of the program as did upper management so if you're not paying attention then it's your fault.

review_title: Work on something that matters, and still pick the kids up from school.
pros: Great work/life balance - you can be a parent and be a professional. Working in Information Systems, you have the chance to work as part of a true "enterprise" - it's not just a buzzword, you really get to support mission-critical systems that affect thousands of users, and be a valued player on an effective team. As a science-based organization, there is better respect for technology than you will find in the IT departments of most non-technology companies.
cons: Working in a technical role is very much being a cog in the machine. You can have your voice heard on purely technical decisions, which is good, and there are chances to (passively) learn about the business issues of Healthcare IT, which is interesting, but it's very difficult to make an impact beyond the predefined scope of the project you're assigned to.

review_title: Direct Managers could use some work
pros: Good coworkers, great benefits, stellar location. Leadership is really taking a focus on modernizing healthcare.
cons: Little focus on growing employees, no support from management, below average pay. My manager questioned my hours and showed me a completely incorrect estimation of what they thought I had been spending my time on. I got sick and my manager told me that I should take less PTO. Another manager ignored my bringing up serious security issues for nearly a year before taking action. Whenever I brought these issues up with higher management, they discounted my experiences and suggested that it was "not my responsibility".

review_title: If you can get a technology job there, take it.
pros:
I was a consultant at Partner's for a few months, and I would have liked to become a permanent employee, but they were using a special medical database and only wanted engineers with a background in that, at the time. They seemed to be doing some very interesting things there. My impression of the place was very positive. My overall experience was good. And it was inspiring to me to work there.

I helped build a patient-tracking system that had the potential to make life easier for patients in the waiting rooms (shorter wait time).  I was given the elbow room to do my job. 

The buildings are nice in the headquarters on the waterfront in Charlestown.

Partner's is a non-profit hospital system, which is also a plus.
cons: I was aware of one problematic manager. But I wasn't really there long enough to get the dirt on any systemic problems with the company.

pros: Good exposure to the cutting edge of medicine and thought leaders in healthcare.  Only good for kids straight out of grad school willing to put in long hours for little pay, but interesting experience.
cons:
Used to be a good place to work.  Incredibly poor leadership and communication in some corporate areas.  Staffers are miserable, and new leadership is clueless--just busy trying to get EPIC installed, and self-promote within the local healthcare scene.  Lots of new staffers in leadership positions with no experience.  It's like watching a slow motion train crash-we see leadership screwing up, they won't take advice from staffers that have been around for a while, but then we are the ones expected to work long hours to correct their missteps.  Morale is terrible and most staffers with experience are actively looking for new jobs.
If you've ever wanted to work at partners, now is your chance.  Just expect long hours, low pay and zero career development.

job_title: Senior Network Engineer in Boston, MA
pros: The benefits..  Clearly the benefits.  There were some fantastic people to work with on an individual basis as well.
cons: Downsides...  Well, they appear to put anyone in management positions, except for the folks that work their tails off.  Don't get me wrong, there are some extremely competent people in leadership positions as well.  I just feel that there's almost a 2:1 ratio of unqualified to qualified managers.

pros: Benefits and they are not that great, but heck we have to get insurance somehow today.
cons: Forced to work Over time. Not enough staff to see patients, patients getting pushed for days . Unable to obtain wound care supplies to care for patients.  Added work monthly and  no adjustments in work schedule or for increased acuity of patients.   Lack of education in the field for clinicians.  No wound care Nurse or IV nurse in the field to assist clinicians or patients.  Management is not visible and they do not care at all what is going on.   They stopped the company and management survey.  over worked and under payed.   it has been a slow decline over the last 2-3 years since new management took over and not for the better.

review_title: Great people, the management needs work and employees are not satisfied
pros:
1) The people you work with are always willing to help if you need it. This is not a company that frowns upon someone who is willing to learn

2) Hours are usually 40 hours a week and is does not deviate from that

3) There is a good mix of people. There are plenty of young people and more seasoned individuals in the latter part of their careers.
cons:
1) Pay is not great  and promotions are based on tenure not achievement. 

2) Management is not particularly helpful in everyday work.

review_title: 3 stars because of benefits, not the work
pros: Benefits are great.  Discounted T pass and on the orange line, good health insurance and retirement benefits.  New building is clean and well laid out with LOTs of conference rooms.  Flexibility with working from home and adjusting hours, is appreciated.
cons: Management is sub-par and very white male.  I'm not sure how promotions occur but it is definitely not based on management skills.  Lots of buzzwords used but less action.  Middle management are not strategic thinkers AND implementers.  There are lots of meetings with lots of discussion about the same issues.

job_title: Registration Service Representative in Medford, MA
pros:
-Great benefits
-Large company, so theres plenty of options to move within the company.
-Great training classes for employees
cons:
-Extreme micro-management
-HR is extremely hard to reach and unresponsive.
-Supervisors that bully employees and excercise favoritism
-Large company but very little room to grow in many departments, many people choose to move on to other companies in healthcare
-The company states it supports employee growth,however, there are very little resources for employees to get the support they need.
-Time off policies are strict, generally you do not have sick-time or vacation time, its condolidated in your "paid time off earnings" .National holidays are deducted from your earned paid time off as well.
-Pay is not so great; pay is under market
-Extreme revolving door, employees come and go very quickly beacuse of the office culture and management

review_title: Partners is a fair company with decent salaries and excellent benefits.
job_title: Applications Analyst II in Wellesley, MA
pros:
Partners is so large that once you are there if you want to grow or change positions there are many opportunities to do so. Furthermore the managers are typically supportive of their employees moving within the company. 

In addition I am able to work from home 1-2 days per week, and my managers are very supportive of my need for work-life balance.
cons:
As with any large organization there are times when it is very political so you need to be prepared for that when working her. Also things tend to move very...slowly... here.
Lastly the compensation, although very fair, is lower than many of my colleagues in other companies within the industry.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Boston, MA
pros:
Beautiful location, 
Wonderful patients, 
Rich learning experience, 
A lot of hands on & self guided work,
Self initiated writing and publishing opportunities
cons:
PI was very unorganized and not present,
Long hours and complicated schedules,
Location-location-location (despite the beauty, it is a bit far can be difficult for clinical trials given patient adherence. Even if there is a shuttle which helps- snow days could be brutal).
I was also there when they let go of a lot of staff- which was dis-concerning how quickly they were willing to drop loyal employees. I didn't get let go, but it was worrisome and changed my perspective on loyalty to Partners.

pros: I have worked for Partners HealthCare (and before that, Newton-Wellesley Hospital- one if its affiliates) for over 30 years. It is a great, innovative employer, offering excellent career growth and a flexible, work-life balance environment. The organization has a strong commitment to research, its patients and the communities that it serves.
cons: The organization,  like and health care employer is facing unprecendented financial challenges due to health care reform, but understands the mission to provide affordable health care and will strike a good balance for employees as well as those for which it provides excellent health care.

review_title: Downhill, cliquey, bureaucratic, sense of entitlement
pros: Great name, solid work-life balance, great benefits, state of the art facility in Somerville
cons: Low pay, a plethora of unqualified and entitled managers (you know who you are), unhelpful and non-existent HR, very silo'd and cliquey between departments and managers, benefits get worse every year, measly merit increases (2%....). Very bureaucratic and hard to rise up as well, and this is because of unqualified management and the nature of the industry. Nobody seems driven here due to the low pay raises and the non-profit type of business it is.

review_title: Great people, pretty old school mindset
pros: Great coworkers, Nice building, Good health insurance
cons: Generally the day to day analytics work can be boring, misguided, or based only what is important to a specific physician leader. This creates numerous situations where resources are being spent on things that really don’t matter to the organization and then result in burnout for data analysts. Leadership would rather appear busy with new work instead of fixing underlying data issues and infrastructure constraints. If you are thinking of applying within the data and analytics organization, really make sure you understand what role you will have and what your job actually entails.

review_title: Working for Partners is not that bad.
job_title: Voice Analyst II Telecommunications in Boston, MA
pros: Benefits are good. Nice people. Rewarding experiences. I work in one of the best areas in Boston. I can park my car right outside the office. They only charge us $75.00 a month which is a steal in Boston. I have great hours and hope to keep it that way.
cons: Management can be old fashion. Not every department is this way. They recently changed our 401K where they are no longer matching per the federal goverment. Money was taken from our Benefits to create a pension plan which is not a bad thing but everyone took a significant hit in their paychecks.

review_title: A cutting edge biomedical research organization
pros: Long list of benefits, wonderful place to work if you are a mom with a kid. Nice 9-5 job, don't have to work overtime or weekends. Located in a great transporation accessible region, near the T, EZ Ride buses, and shuttle services. People have typically good work ethics and are polite! Great place to work, great learning environment, and located right smack near a lot of restaurants and food services for a wonderful lunch break!
cons: Need better salaries for the people below management. For the big research organization it is, and though it is nonprofit, the salary is just not cutting it in this down-trodden economy where costs of almost everything are rising. Other than that, Partners is a respectable place to work in Boston metro.

pros: Job training, career planning. Opportunities to move around in Partners among the entities for job postings. Fantastic mentoring when you can find it.
cons: Bureacracy everywhere you turn. Process driven. I suppose this is what made Partners Healthcare what it is in the 1990's, but it's time to move on. Mediocre salaries (nobody's getting rich here, unless you are in R&D or an MD).

review_title: Great benefits, really large healthcare corporate
pros:
In many ways a great culture - non-profit, working with healthcare professionals to improve care or a large network of leading hospitals. The benefits are great, from health care (of course) to employee perks like access to sporting and concert tickets and other corporate discounts. Time off is fair. I have a fabulous manager.

Not only are the health care benefits good from a cash point of view, access to some of the best care makes up for what might be a slightly less competitive salary. 

Ultimately the best reward is positively affecting patient care, even in the most distant type of role that isn't directly helping patients.
cons:
So large, it's almost impossible to effect change. Bureaucratic - some of this is because of healthcare regulations and the like, but sometimes the number of middle managers gets in the way of decision making or structurally inhibits cross-team communication. 

Their excuse is that they're a non-profit, and that policy doesn't allow it -- a move to a role that should have paid 20% more did not see a raise of anywhere near that. Stayed because ultimately the skills built will allow me to move elsewhere in six months and earn significantly more. So I consider it an investment in my career, however if they want to retain talent this is a poor strategy.

review_title: An employer that pretends to care about its employees when it really couldn't care less
pros: Decent health benefits -that's about it.
cons: Sprawling bureaucracy... nowhere to turn with concerns. Senior and middle management direct their efforts towards APPEARING to care, rather than the hard work of actually providing support, resources, and open lines of communication.

review_title: Great hospitals, interesting work, uncertain organizational structure
pros:
Cutting edge healthcare issues
Mission-driven focus, sense of true purpose
Committed to providing top-quality care
Extraordinary hospitals and providers
Great colleagues
Challenging, motivating work
cons:
Culture varies greatly among hospitals and departments;  hard to feel part of the "whole"
Underlying tension/discomfort between Partners and hospitals
Extremely varied opportunities for advancement, from a lot in some areas to none at all
Lack of connection between stated values and actions
Constant discussion of budget cuts while employees very overworked, trying to fill in gaps
Managers not always suited for positions

review_title: Partners Healthcare - A Great Place To Work
job_title: Registered Respiratory Therapist in Boston, MA
pros: There are a number of hospitals that you can work for and all use the same software, payroll, etc. Partners also has a number of perks for working with them, such as discounted events that are changed weekly. In addition, the hospitals are large and well-known with good reputations. It's nice to work for a place where you can easily switch between different hospitals and positions.
cons: Some of the hospitals sometimes try to cut costs where they shouldn't be cut. For instance, trying to downsize departments that are vital to patient care. I think there are cuts that should be made in other areas, but not those that are deeply involved in patient care and safety.

pros: Partners is a good place to work. I have been here for over 6 years. My work is interesting and I like what I do. Some nice features - good HR benefits and good work/life balance. I feel my dept knows work is important but values people also. I definitely like I'm part of a team.
cons: My dept has changed over the years and the culture really depends on the managers on staff. Like anywhere, there can be conflicts with challenging people, inexperienced managers, etc., but overall, it's a good place to work. One other thing is that the compensation is not as good as other healthcare IS companies/hospitals for the same job/role/tasks.

review_title: I enjoyed my position and most of my co-workers. Lots of +s to working at Partners. Extra hours and no pay is expected.
pros: Training, schooling and on-line classes was available and encouraged. Some compensation available.
cons: The work load is tremendous and impossible to do within specified hours. You are expected to complete all tasks even if it means you stay after hours. You are NOT compensated for extra work.  You must choose to keep your job or lose it by blowing the whistle. Most choose slavery to keep their position.

job_title: Systems Support Technician in Boston, MA
pros:
Great hours
Good benefits
Nice co-workers
Generally a nice place to work to collaborate with other team members
Upper management is excellent and stays communicated with employees.
cons:
Salaries needs to be reviewed & compared with other healthcare organizations
Lack of communication between depts when implimenting new policies or procedures.
Managers not familar with their workers resonsiblities possibly due to not understanding their job functions

review_title: Great Work/Life Balance BUT Compensation is lacking
pros: As I mentioned in the title, there is a great work/life balance-which makes up for sub-par pay.  Benefits here are excellent. There is paternity leave as well (up to three months).  If you work in the corporate office you can work from home.
cons: There isn't a standard path to getting promotions.  You have to leave one department and then go to another in order to be promoted.  Lack of training courses for business (i.e. Visio and Access).  Compensation has a lot left to be desired.  Standard 2% "merit" raise is essentially an inflationary raise.

review_title: New to healthcare?  Prepare to slow it down... a lot!
pros: It affords a VERY lax lifestyle.  You can work on a plethora of things outside of your normal work day.  The culture is such that everyone is always so "busy" when in reality most everyone is still out of the door by 4pm at the latest.
cons:
If you actually want to do work, you can become bored out of your mind.
The culture tends to breed incredibly passive aggressive communication styles.

pros: Flexible work hours, no micro-management, can work from home as much as needed. Great benefits. Immediate group works well as a team. Hospital staff is generally pleasant to work with. Work feels meaningful because of its close connection to patient care.
cons: No chance for growth. Everyone gets a flat 2% raise every year regardless of performance. Many meetings in which we are warned that Partners is "tightening its belt". Potential layoffs after Epic conversion. Corporate Values Statement doesn't match the reality of the culture. Teamwork between different corporate groups is not good; some groups are obstructive or unresponsive.

pros: Overall, OK place to work, but list of cons has been growing each year.
cons: Biggest Cons:  Pay raises are below most Cost of Living rates of increase and the benefits have been steadily decreasing every year.  Management constantly complains company is not profitable, but company is supposedly a "Non-Profit"...

pros: Great people, eventually you accrue tons of vacation time and there is a great work/life balance. If you can finish your work, people do not mind if you leave early any day. Health benefits are great, I am able to get an appointment at MGH anytime I feel sick or want to a check up within a day!
cons: Pay, Pay, Pay. As someone who has been here since college and been promoted a number of times, I have yet to be able to really dictate my raises. HR plays hardball with you and really does not budge on numbers ever.

pros: Big company with a wide network of hospitals.  They provide very good employee benefits such as health insurance (dental, vision, etc) and for continuing education they provide salary reimbursement.
cons: As a good example of a big company, changes (if any) happen very slowly.  There is not much room to step up in the assigned work tasks.  You need to be ok with what you're doing because you'll be doing it for a long time.

review_title: Enjoyed working with a variety of people at a company dedicated to healthcare
job_title: Applications Analyst II in Boston, MA
pros: There is tons of training. They are quite flexible with work at home and family life work balance. Benefits are excellent. There are a lot of opportunities to move around within the network if you're good.
cons: Partners eCare will cause a lot of people to be laid off, and it's not always the last in, it may be the least liked. There is no union. Salaries are low compared to the industry (or they were).

review_title: With over 95 opportunites available good luck gettng one!!
job_title: Senior EMR Implementation Build Specialist in Boston, MA
pros: None to share to date
cons: I am  Senior EMR Implementation specialist with over 10+ years with a full Certification in an existing EMR. I have applied to so many of the open postings and due to the grossly understaffing with the HR recruiters it is IMPOSSIBLE to get an interview with any of the Partners HR staff.. Your only hope is that you get a respose from Ranstad which will only if you are lucky will secure you a contract position. I am sorely disappointed in the Partners hiring process so I wish all of the Senior EMR candidates the best of luck going forward...

review_title: Top in providing health care services; internally some silos exist
pros: Provides tremendous service to the public - teaching hospitals with great community outreach.  Good benefits.  Some areas can approach work/life balance; there is a corporate remote work program.
cons: While programs like MS Office and the enterprise health record program is being approached as an enterprise offering, many other programs and projects are approached only at the department level, and thus don't take full advantage of enterprise implementation.  This can cause some training issues and a lot of effort to get siloed systems to communicate.

pros: Good place to start a career and understand how a large organization operates as well as gain industry specific knowledge.
cons:
Many people who have been there for a long time are unproductive or are very resistant to change. This results in poor processes and a poor quality of work. Some managers will try their best to help you because ultimately they realize the better you do the less work they have to do. Some managers will treat you like garbage and hope you leave after a year so they can continue the cycle and have job security for themselves. (I cannot express how detrimental this is to a business). However, your managers boss does not care either way and a manager at Partners Healthcare is nothing more than an administrative assistant for HR duties for their assigned workers, but that’s about the extent of their power. So, you will work hard you will learn and that is about it. You probably won’t get promoted, you probably won’t be making market rate salary but you’ll have great exposure and a great building. Get the name on your resume, get some experience and knowledge and then leave.

P.S. If you go to HR, your manager will know about it even after they say they won’t tell your manager. So if you are going to do it, be prepared.

review_title: Interesting work, good people, but deterioration of company culture over time
pros:
Get exposure to the hot topics in healthcare financing
Can work at home
Associated with Partners Healthcare, so there can be career mobility
cons:
Working at home was nice, but so many people are doing it that the company culture deteriorated.
May become unstable because of changes in healthcare financing.

job_title: Human Resources Generalist in Boston, MA
pros: It's a great place to learn a lot and add to your skill set.  It's an extremely diverse employee population.  The benefits were also really great.
cons: Budget cuts in healthcare led to a LOT more work with no added pay.  Often over-utilized and under-appreciated.

job_title: Human Resources Sourcing Specialist in Somerville, MA
pros: I have been at Partners for just under 6 months and have had nothing but a great experience so far.  The new building at Assembly Row was built to promote collaboration and teamwork and as far as I can see it has served its purpose.  I have felt welcomed since my very first day.  I am on a great team that is there to support and help each other in any way they can.  The benefits that are offered are very competitive.  I highly recommend Partners Healthcare.
cons: None that I can see.

pros: Tons of learning opportunities, working with world class clinicians, focus on patient care,  can move around within the company.
cons: Dramatic culture change with Epic rip and replace of current systems.  Lots of new people and confusion, deadline driven without attention to quality.  No one talks about patient care or patient safety anymore, it's all about making your dates. Managers are in meetings all day and no longer able to provide coaching or mentorship.  Feels like just another corporate job.

review_title: a humble review from an analyst
pros: Partners is a large company with name value within the health care world.  Partners has numerous entities throughout Massachusetts, providing many career move possibilities.  Other companies in the area recognize Partners as a good company to work for.  Many consulting companies have sought Partners employees.  The hours are regular and people rarely take work home or work overtime.
cons: The pay is average, Paid-Time-Off is very limited and vacations are few.

job_title: Senior Project Manager in Boston, MA
pros: Benefits are very good, of course the health care is the best!  If you leave Partners you find how many out of pocket expenses there are.  They have a great time off policy and you can buy extra days off.  In general find the benefits to be outstanding.
cons: There are few 'spot bonuses' and found it hard to recognize work that goes above and beyond expectations.  Could use better incentives for those who are doing a really good job and should be rewarded.

review_title: Worst place I have ever worked! Patient Services Coordinator
pros: The only pro about working here is the health insurance benefits.  They have a great plan that is inexpensive.  If all you want is a great health plan this is a great place to work.
cons:
HR policies don't apply to everyone (one person gets an exception and another doesn't)
No growth opportunity
Paid way below industry standards
Terrible management (they don't listen and have horrible people skills)
Awful time off  policy (not generous at all like some other hospitals)
Too many managers and not enough workers
Management could care less what any of the people actually doing the work have to say
Overall worst place in Massachusetts to work!

review_title: A supportive company with plenty of opportunity
pros:
The intern program included a lot of educational activities and opportunities to meet various leaders through out the organization.
Managers were very helpful and I received plenty of constructive feedback that helped me professionally.
I was treated like an equal within my department, rather than just an intern.
cons:
Such a large organization, it felt disconnected at times
Everyone was very busy, so it was difficult to find a time to meet with my manager or have my questions answered - more of an individual environment where you have to be self-motivated. This makes it easy to go unnoticed.

review_title: Large healthcare management organization with great benefits but slow uptake to change.
pros: Great benefits and compensation. Team members are all very accomplished in their field and knowledgeable. Lots of opportunities for advancement and professional development.
cons: As a very large organization (50,000+ employees in total) the wheels of change and adaptation are slow. PHI would benefit greatly from being more agile and flexible, especially when working in international locations.

pros: staff are knowledgeable and helpful to one another. Insurance benefits
cons: long hours, no backing of staff, no transparency, a lot of management and not enough ground workers, lack of time off,

review_title: Good non-profit entity to work for with a multitude of career options
pros: Lots of different positions available throughout the corporate side. Location in Assembly Row can be convenient to get to if you live in the right location. The work I do is engaging and has real long-term career potential.
cons:
Your enjoyment will likely depend on the individual job you have. Some positions will be great with fantastic managers, others I'm sure are probably taxing.

Can be hard to get started here, but once you are in you have access to a lot of options at Partners.

pros: As a resident in the Partners system, you are working within a large academic community and are around some of the best and brightest. it also provided me with the opportunity to receive great training in a variety of different hospital settings, as the residencies tend to span across a number of hospitals.  Partners also has a great number of resources available to be accessed.  I felt that the level of compensation for residents and the benefits were significantly better than in many other cities, though Boston is known as the city with overall high rates of compensation (relatively speaking) for residents in training.
cons: As a resident, the hours worked are long, and opportunities to have a life out side of medicine is quite difficult.  Additionally, the fact that there are many of the "best and brightest" unfortunately often means that you also have some of the most narcissistic individuals and that departments do not always work well together, with many departments thinking that they are better than other departments and not respecting their work.  Additionally the lack of off-site access to electronic medical records for charting or completing notes etc. was a pain, especially when trying to document phone calls etc.  Most other hospital systems of its caliber had a much easier way to access EMR from off-site.  While Partners theoretically had it available, the vast majority of us were never able to actually get it to work.

job_title: Applications Analyst II  in Boston, MA
pros: Acess to cutting edge technology.  It is exciting to set the industry standard for many areas of IT.  We have the opportunity to learn and guide others.
cons: Large organization - lots of politics.  The career development path can be difficult because it is such a large organization.  There is a lot of geographical separation and silos of work.

pros: Management isn't overbearing and generally is content to let you do your thing. The environment is relaxed with a relaxed dress code unless face to face meetings with clients are required. Overall people are very friendly which is a very pleasant experience.
cons:
No real training when I came aboard. It was with the grace of a couple of competent and willing coworkers that I was able to find my footing. Basically you were introduced to a few applicable templates and a couple locations for applicable materials and that was it. 

Management, as a whole, did not seem to understand the nature of their job and seemed more interested in the volume then the quality to the point where it became dangerous because of potential legal implications. 

No reference materials were provided for an individual to even be able learn on their own and management could not name even half of the applicable policies and procedures that were necessary to perform the services.  There was a general feeling many in management positions were not qualified to run these particular departments. 

The handling of the departments budget were questionable given that the amount of work was increasing steadily and yet they were consistently trimming down the office to the point where everyone was completely overworked and were not able to assist their end users in an appropriate time based on the sheer amount of work on their desk. Additionally many employees were not salaried and overtime was discouraged and for the most part not allowed management actually expressed genuine surprise no one was able to produce quality work for every single end user in a 40 hr work week. 

The sad part is with good management and a better system in place this could be a great job on every front.

review_title: Partners Healthcare - Brigham and Women's Hospital
job_title: Software Engineer I in Boston, MA
pros: The environment is a rich opportunity for a lay person to learn about hospitals and the art of healing.
cons:
The Hospital tends to hire those who were not brought up in the tradition of good old fashion American teamwork. Instead, they see every work day as a competition just to look better than the rest of us by lying, cheating, mud slinging and taking undeserved credit. They resort to daily micro-aggressions to wear out anyone trying to do good work. When they eventually connive their way into group leader and manager roles there was a mass exit of the good team members. For crying out loud, a hospital is no place for dirty politics, where all that energy can be better directed at saving patients' lives, not enhancing one's own career.

And there are the arrogant MD/PhD types who are so full of themselves that they can't tolerate being contradicted by subordinates and are very vindictive. They squash  open, honest discussions by yelling  and ridiculing the opposing points of view. Just because they are high up in the academic pecking order doesn't mean they are mature, intelligent, sensitive adults. They are not qualified to manage anything more intelligent than a potted plant let alone a lab.

It is an understatement to remark how Partners Healthcare lacks transparency. In the past, employees are suddenly "disappeared" with no explanation. Wide reaching decision-making even at a laboratory or sub-department level is done behind closed doors. Inexplicably, obviously unfit candidates are nevertheless hired by the managers disregarding the honest feedback from the interview panel. It raises suspicions that something nefarious is always going on.

Don't be fooled by the claim that Partners Healthcare provides a generous vacation package. You may work tirelessly and without a break all year long but managers will not permit you to take more than 10 days off at the end of the year even though you will lose your unspent vacation days.

Also don't be mislead to think you can find ways to compensate for the low salary offered to work at Partners. The maximum raise you will get is 2% annually, if at all. The benefits are much less generous than what you can get elsewhere in this economy of 2017. Your coworkers will turn out to have been hired with sub-standard technical, communication, and social skills because they were rejected by more selective employers. Taking the whole compensation package together plus the quality of life, you will carry on a miserable, meager existence compared to your counterparts outside of Partners.

To put it into proper perspective, the big name surgeons and scientific researchers are the superstars of the Hospital because they bring in the revenues and the prestige.  Everyone else are considered merely auxiliary and dispensable. Compensation and benefits are doled out accordingly.

As sure sign of management's disregard for employees, we were a team of 6 programmers who were crammed into a two-person office. Being elbow to elbow like that made it extremely difficult to concentrate and be productive . It felt like being on an 18th century slave ship every day, year after year.
